Subject: Re: [neat] Evolving Soft Robots with CPPNs (New Paper & Video)

Hi Randy,

I do the same in many figures (e.g. Fig. 23, 11, etc. in http://=
jeffclune.com/publications/2011-CluneEtAl-IndirectEncodingAcrossRegularityC=
ontinuum-IEEE-TEC.pdf).

But, I also include a p-value. 

I believe it is i=
ncorrect to just show standard error as you have done and not report a p-va=
lue, a lesson I learned at MSU from Lenski, Ofria, and others. Oftentimes s=
omething looks significant on a plot with variance, especially if you use s=
uch a generous variance indicator as standard error. What would be the harm=
 in also including a p-value in addition to your visualization of the data =
and variance? Do you have any modern stats articles that argue in favor of =
this practice? I am asking because as a reviewer I would complain if I saw =
this practice, and if I am incorrectly complaining I'd like to know so I do=
 not make unjustified requests/complaints in my reviews. I do know that som=
e statisticians do advocate not using p-values, but I wasn't under the impr=
ession that the alternative was simply to remove a p-value and leave in an =
typical plot with average+/- some indication of variance. I assumed that th=
ere was something else, more complicated, that they would substitute in pla=
ce of the p-value. 


Best regards,
Jeff Clune

Assistant Professor
Compute=
r Science
University of Wyoming
jeffclune@...
jeffclune.com

On Jun 4,=
 2013, at 6:44 AM, rhiever489 <rhiever@...> wrote:

> > That sounds t=
o me like you are just reinventing something very similar to a p-value, and=
 that serves the same purpose as a p-value=85.and also falls prey to all th=
e same objections that the post raised against p-values. I still haven't he=
ard a good reason why p-values are not helpful when properly thought about =
(though I recognize that many don't think properly about them). 
> 
> See, =
e.g., Figure 6 in our GECCO paper: http://www.randalolson.com/wp-content/up=
loads/Olson-Critical-Interplay-Between-Density-dependent-Predation-and-Evol=
ution-of-the-Selfish-Herd-2013.pdf
> 
> It's useful for showing evolutionar=
y trends and that those trends significantly differ for the measurement you=
 are using.
> 
> 


--Apple-Mail=_7CD758AB-0B7B-4E5E-B0F6-B1AEE5D51CDE

    <div id=3D"ygrp-text"><p>> That=
 sounds to me like you are just reinventing something very similar to a p-v=
alue, and that serves the same purpose as a p-value=85.and also falls prey =
to all the same objections that the post raised against p-values. I still h=
aven't heard a good reason why p-values are not helpful when properly thoug=
ht about (though I recognize that many don't think properly about them). <b=
r>
<br>
See, e.g., Figure 6 in our GECCO paper: <a href=3D"http://www.randa=
lolson.com/wp-content/uploads/Olson-Critical-Interplay-Between-Density-depe=
ndent-Predation-and-Evolution-of-the-Selfish-Herd-2013.pdf">http://www.rand=
alolson.com/wp-content/uploads/Olson-Critical-Interplay-Between-Density-dep=
endent-Predation-and-Evolution-of-the-Selfish-Herd-2013.pdf</a><br>
<br>
It=
's useful for showing evolutionary trends and that those trends significant=
ly differ for the measurement you are using.<br>
<br>
